content: The "Outer Continental Shelf Natural Gas Relief Act" terminates prohibitions on expenditures for offshore gas leasing and revokes withdrawals of Federal submerged lands for leasing. It also establishes an Outer Continental Shelf leasing program. SEC. 10. STATE APPROVAL REQUIREMENT WITH RESPECT TO GAS LEASING. The Secretary cannot grant gas leases within 20 miles of a state's coastline without the state's approval. The Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act requires lease sales to offer at least 75% of available unleased acreage in each planning area for gas leasing. The amendment allows for gas leasing on the Outer Continental Shelf within each planning area, applying to the 5-year leasing program in effect at the time of enactment and all future programs. The amendment allows for gas leasing on the Outer Continental Shelf within each planning area, applying to the 5-year leasing program in effect at the time of enactment and all future programs. SEC. 4. SHARING OF REVENUES. The amendment to the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act allows for gas leasing on submerged lands within State boundaries, with revenue sharing provisions for bonus bids and royalties. The amendment to the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act allows for gas leasing on submerged lands within State boundaries, with revenue sharing provisions for bonus bids and royalties. 40% of revenue goes to the State, 10% for the Low-Income Home Energy Assistance Program, and the rest to the State from existing gas leases on submerged lands. The Outer Continental Shelf Natural Gas Relief Act stipulates that States will receive a percentage of amounts received from gas leasing on submerged lands within their seaward boundaries, with increasing percentages over the first four fiscal years after the enactment of the Act. The Outer Continental Shelf Natural Gas Relief Act states that States will receive a percentage of amounts from gas leasing on submerged lands within their seaward boundaries, increasing over the first four fiscal years after the Act's enactment. The Outer Continental Shelf Natural Gas Relief Act stipulates that States will receive a percentage of bonus bids and royalties from gas leasing on submerged lands within their seaward boundaries, based on the percentage of surface acreage of the tract within those boundaries. Definitions for "existing Federal gas lease" and "new Federal gas lease" are provided in the Act. The Outer Continental Shelf Natural Gas Relief Act establishes that States will receive a portion of bonus bids and royalties from gas leasing on submerged lands within their seaward boundaries. The Act defines "new Federal gas lease" as a lease granted after the enactment date. Additionally, the Act amends the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act to clarify the establishment of State seaward boundaries. The Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act is amended to extend lines as indicated on maps for each outer Continental Shelf region. The maps are titled 'Alaska OCS Region State Adjacent Zone and OCS Planning Areas', 'Pacific OCS Region State Adjacent Zones and OCS Planning Areas', 'Gulf of Mexico OCS Region State Adjacent Zones and OCS Planning Areas', and 'Atlantic OCS Region State Adjacent Zones and OCS Planning Areas', dated September 2005. SEC. 5. NATURAL GAS-ONLY LEASING. Section 8 of the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act is amended to allow the Secretary to issue leases for natural gas and associated condensate production, with regulations defining natural gas, condensate, and oil, establishing lessee rights and obligations, and outlining procedures and requirements. The amendment to Section 8 of the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act allows the Secretary to issue leases for natural gas and associated condensate production, with regulations defining rights and obligations for lessees, including procedures for discovering oil deposits during exploration or development. All provisions of federal laws and regulations that apply to oil and natural gas leases also apply to natural gas-only leases authorized under this subsection. The Secretary can issue natural gas-only leases for the outer Continental Shelf without amending existing oil and gas leases. This provision is part of the oil and gas leasing programs under the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act. The Secretary can issue natural gas-only leases for the outer Continental Shelf without amending existing oil and gas leases, as part of the leasing programs under the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act. The leases can be issued before June 30, 2007, with public notice and comment, and for the 5-year period starting in 2007.
